GET TO KNOW: Great teachers are our pride!

👩‍🏫 Kaire Viil is a recognized Estonian language lecturer at the college and has long led the Humanities Working Group. In addition to language studies, she teaches College Studies, Communication Psychology, Basics of Expression Teaching and Presentation. Kaire is an enterprising person and injects it into both colleagues and students.

Kaire has acquired in-depth knowledge of andragogy. He is a member of ANDRAS and an ambassador of EPALE Estonia. She has level 7 of the adult educator profession and is applying for the highest level 8. In 2020, he received a diploma in management coaching and continues to study team coaching.
Kaire has been the first lecturer in the college to receive the e-course quality badge and has been selected as the TÕN trainer of the year for the adult learner week in 2018.

💐 Kaire has been nominated by the college as a TUT Teacher of the Year 2020 candidate.

GET TO KNOW: Great teachers are our pride!

👩‍🏫 Olga Dunajeva, who has a doctorate, is a developer of data science and machine learning in the field of telematics and intelligent systems, and a supervisor of dissertations and internships. Olga is an excellent teacher who teaches a total of 7 subjects, including one in English. In addition, he manages to conduct in-service training, teach schoolchildren and constantly acquire new knowledge.

💐 The college recognized Olga with the title of Developer of the Year 2020 and she has been nominated by the college as a TUT Teacher of the Year 2020 candidate. He was chosen by the students as the teacher with the best Moodle environment of 2020.

GET TO KNOW: Great teachers are our pride!

👨‍💼 Junior lecturer Aleksei Hõbesaar is a graduate of Virumaa College who studied energy technology. Immediately after graduating in 2019, he joined the family of college faculty. Alekse is valued as an active, conscientious and kind teacher. In addition to teaching, she participates in popularizing the curriculum for school students, participates in science theater and is a mentor for freshmen. Students have said, “I don't know how he can communicate with everyone. He is simply polite and has no unnecessary ambitions. Alexei deserves trust - just like a human being. ”

💐 Alekse was recognized by the College with the title of Young Colleague of the Year 2020.

GET TO KNOW: Great teachers are our pride!

👩‍🏫 Veroonika Shirokova, who has a doctorate, is the program manager and senior lecturer of full-time and session students in the three major curricula of the college. In addition to his daily work, he manages the college's sectoral development team, participates in development projects, actively promotes the curriculum and conducts in-service training.

💐 The College recognized Veronica with the title of Teacher of the Year 2020 and has been nominated by the College as a TUT Teacher of the Year 2020 candidate. She has been chosen by students as her favorite teacher of the year 2020. In 2019, Veroonika College was awarded the title of the best teacher of the year and the title of the best lecturer in the city of Kohtla-Järve.

✅ Virumaa College will continue its hybrid studies and will prepare for the end of the semester and exam session in new conditions.

👇 Study and work organization in TalTech from December 14 👇
📌From Monday, December 14 until the beginning of the new year (unless the government decides otherwise), we apply distance learning in all curricula to conduct studies.
📌 Examinations, assessments, tests, personal consultations and practical training are allowed at the university, but all safety measures must be observed: university entrants must be healthy and must not be isolated. The 2 + 2 rule must be followed, hands must be disinfected and masks must be worn.
📌 Application of the 2 + 2 rule in auditoriums: sitting in a chessboard pattern, behind two and three tables alone. In the case of long rows, the space between two persons is two seats, they sit across the row, one row between them is left empty.
📌 Examination times can be found in ÕIS. If the time of the examination or the organization of the examination is changed, the students must be notified and the change must be formalized in the SIS.
📌 If the student is self-isolated or ill during the examination, we ask the student to contact the lecturer and find a suitable solution for the examination together.

The Oil Shale Competence Center of TalTech Virumaa College, in cooperation with Estonian oil shale industry companies, has been compiling an overview of industry as well as scientific developments for 6 years.

Exciting reading! We recommend! 🤩

TalTech Virumaa College Oil Shale Competence Center
16 November 2020 at 16:51 ·

In 2019, the oil shale sector employed 6,530 people and contributed 121 million euros to the state treasury. The oil shale industry underwent a major change in 2019, as the main mineral resource, mined 16 million tonnes, produced 54% less electricity, while the production of liquid fuels reached an all-time high of 1.17 million tonnes.

The yearbook, published for the 6th year, was compiled by the oil shale competence center of TalTech Virumaa College, Eesti Energia, Viru Keemia Grupp and Kiviõli Keemiatööstuse OÜ. The extradition was supported by the EU's European Regional Development Fund.

▶ ️Read the Estonian yearbook: www.bit.ly/polevkivi_aastkönyv2019

In the largest auditorium of the college, important guests are talking about the oil shale industry and its future today.

▶ ️ See also the live broadcast: https://www.onlineexpo.com/ee/polevkivikonverents/

TalTech Virumaa College Oil Shale Competence Center

Allan Niidu, Professor of Applied Chemistry at Virumaa College and Research Manager of the Oil Shale Competence Center of TalTech Virumaa College, believes that hydrogen production capacity should be created in Estonia. "The production of methanol or another suitable chemical from CO2 and / or bio-waste should be started, as CO2 and biomass are widely available in Estonia, even from shale oil or electricity production, and biomass is also a by-product of the forest industry or agriculture."

⁉️ Did you know that Mare Roosileht was elected the director of TalTech Virumaa College in 2019? He worked as a mathematics and informatics teacher at Virumaa College from 2000 to 2001, as the head of the Mathematics and Informatics Lecturer from 2002, from 2004 as the head of the Real Center, and from 2007 as the Development Director of Virumaa College. In 2020, Mare Roosileht was awarded the title of Ida-Virumaa Maker of the Year.
The story of the college's 20-year period is now in the glass gallery between the university library and the Faculty of Economics in Tallinn until October 16. 🖼

Viru Keemia Grupp
8 July 2020 at 14:01 ·

👷Get to know - Gunnar Joonas. Gunnar worked for Viru Keemia Grupp for 5 years before moving to Germany to work for a global technology company. We asked him to describe his career at VKG and asked if and how working at VKG helped him get his current job.

"I started my career at VKG as an automation system maintenance worker in February 2012. After a few months, I was increasingly involved in design work. As soon as the Petroter II project went green, I was assigned to an automation project team and only worked in design. Shortly after the end of the project, I started working in the Petroter III project team.
The aforementioned major projects and countless smaller side projects brought a huge amount of experience and knowledge. There I had the honor of collaborating with the best and smartest colleagues. I also took an extremely positive experience from VKG in the form of a nice team.

I worked at VKG for a little over five years. The plan was to learn as quickly as possible and as much as possible, as this is an extremely interesting profession and every professional should learn something new every day to keep up with new technical trends. The main goal was not to get to the highest position, but to make the job interesting. That was for me and is still the main driver.

I am currently an automation project manager at a large international design and manufacturing company. The experience gained at VKG has been enormous, as the experience gained in the oil industry is doubly worthwhile in other industries. "
#VKG #VKGs #careers inVKGs

6 July 2020 at 09:00 ·

👨‍🔬Today we introduce the graduate of TalTech Virumaa College and the deputy head of our electrode coke unit Kiryli.
Kiryl is from Belarus, where she received two degrees and worked as a head of the administrative department at a prestigious university. 🧐We asked Kiryl why he decided to give up a good job at home and come to Estonia to study chemistry.

"It was a big adventure that changed my life radically. My first education is related to environmental science, my second is economics. I had never worked in production, I didn't even know what was ahead of me. Then I started studying. Weeks passed, then months, and practice awaited. I researched a bit of the background, it turned out that right next to it is the world class chemical industry. I ran for office, I got hit, ”says Kiryl.

"During the internship, I drew in front of my eyes what my specialty is. The more I learned, the more I fell in love. I expressed my wish to work for VKG. I became the operator of a defenolator. Since I felt that I missed my vocational education, I went to TUT Virumaa College to study for a master's degree in fuel chemistry and technology. Time had to be divided between work, university and vocational school. It was pretty crazy, but I did it. I am currently working at VKG as the Vice President of the Electrode Coke Plant. ”
#VKG #VKGs #TalTech # Go to study

Tallinn University of Technology
18 May 2020 at 15:27 ·

On Monday, May 18, the Council of Tallinn University of Technology elected Professor Tiit Landi Rector of the University.

Tiit Land has been the Rector of Tallinn University since 2011. He was a professor of neurochemistry at Stockholm University from 2000 to 2006, a professor of chemistry at Tallinn University from 2007, and from 2008 to 2011 he was the director of the Institute of Mathematics and Natural Sciences at Tallinn University.

Land received his doctorate in neurochemistry and neurotoxicology from Stockholm University in 1994 and completed his postdoctoral fellowship at the American National Institute of Health from 1994 to 1999.

In her election platform, Tiit Land has said that as the rector of Tallinn University of Technology, she intends to proceed from the mission and vision set in the university's development plan for 2020. Its goal is to increase the academic quality of the university over the next five years, to increase the quality and volume of research and development work, and to initiate the preparation of an action plan for the principles of the internationalization of the university and the principles of sustainable development.

📌 Tiit Landi was nominated as a rector candidate by a group of academicians of the Estonian Academy of Sciences.
📌 Tiit Land will take office as the Rector of Tallinn University of Technology on September 1. The term of office of the Rector is five years.

Researchers are studying the possibilities of producing shale oil from plastic waste

TalTech Virumaa College Oil Shale Competence Center
14 May 2020 at 13:20 ·

The Oil Shale Competence Center is a research partner for Eesti Energia in the smart specialization project. The research, which will be carried out over a year and a half, aims to find out how waste plastic can be used in industrial oil production and waste that cannot be recycled can be turned into a valuable liquid fuel.

"Within the framework of this project, it is possible to systematically use the results of basic research and at the same time identify the factors on which further successful implementation depends. The answer is laboratory and bench tests. In case of success, this is a big step to increase the role of oil shale processing in the context of the circular economy, "explained our senior researcher Hella Riisalu.

Today is WORLD DIGITAL CLEANING DAY! Take a moment today to review your emails, pictures, files and programs, and delete any that you no longer need.

Virumaa College also took part in the day of digital cleaning on January 25, and then the total volume of our cleaning was 284.5GB!

World Harvest Day in Estonia
22 April 2020 at 07:06 ·

🧹🌎 WE ALSO CLEAN DIGITAL PRINTING!

Do you know the moment when you run out of boredom on social media without a goal? We have a wonderful alternative for you today!
Take 👉30 minutes👈, check your e-mail, phone and / or computer, and delete obsolete files, duplicate or blurry pictures, stalled applications, and programs.

🤔 WHY CLEAN DIGITAL PRINTING?
Your devices are getting faster, saving your users valuable time. Organized devices also have a good effect on mental health. Of course, the environmental impact of your equipment is also reduced.
❗️ Namely, more than half of the world's population uses the Internet, which emits the same amount of CO2 as all air traffic. By 2025, a fifth of the world's energy needs are projected to be stored in data storage, making it one of the biggest polluters.

🥵 I DON'T UNDERSTAND WHAT IT ALL MEANS ...
Don't worry, there is a lot of information about this, but digital pollution has been studied for years. For example, Rabih Bashroush, a researcher at the University of East London, calculated that the 5 billion webcasts of the 2017 hit story Despacito consumed as much electricity as Chad, Guinea-Bissau, Somalia, Sierra Leone and the Central African Republic combined in one year.

🧐 WHY WORLD DIGITAL CLEANING DAY?
"I have to constantly remind myself that, unlike an attic or a basement, where unnecessary things can be stored, computers and servers take up resources and literally heat up our planet," says Mart Normet, the leader of the Estonian World Harvest.
❗️ "Of course it's hard to predict if a particular file may ever be needed again, but let's be honest - we can't even search for most!"

According to server service provider Zone Media resident hacker Peeter Marvet, the size of the average mailbox is approaching one gigabyte. "Users are willing to pay for a 25 or 50 gigabyte mailbox - but most of it is" unsorted municipal waste, "which takes time and effort to delete or archive," comments Marvet. "I see similar digital waste on web servers every day - old versions, long-running campaigns, backups and backups of backups. "At some point, they will become 'nuclear waste' - a risk for you, an opportunity for someone to misuse it."

🤩 WHO ELSE INVOLVED IN DIGITAL CLEANING?
Anneli Ohvril, the leader of the Digital Harvest Day, says that 26 countries have already confirmed their participation in the Digital Harvest Day, the largest of which are Russia, Indonesia, Turkey, Argentina and Togo. "It is still difficult to predict the exact number of participants, but we are expecting participants from all countries in our network," commented Victim.

We hope you now understand why old photos or stalled videos on your devices are unnecessary. Share the call with your friends, family and co-workers - let's make digital equipment clean!

Every company, organization, institution, school and even class has its own leader / teacher face!
The first lesson I learned during my university studies was when my pedagogy teacher made it clear that if we want students to be caring, honest, curious, etc., it is we, their teachers, who have to take responsibility. We must set an example by every act, word, or behavior we take. I have repeatedly and repeatedly confirmed the truth of this message over the years.
Now, as the head of the college, I often look in the mirror and ask if everything is exactly as our students, employees, partners and employers expect. I realize that there is still a lot to do! We and our team have developed an action plan and are taking small but firm steps toward our Great Surprisingly Bold Goal. This cannot be done by the leader alone, but still with his motivated and committed staff and students. The team of Virumaa College is the best possible! Thank you to our people for the great work they do every day!
The face of every (university) depends on instruction. Good school leaders! Let's take responsibility for our students and staff! Let's cooperate and make the educational life of Ida-Virumaa the best in Estonia!

Today was a working day in Ida-Virumaa!

Last year, the government extended the action plan of Ida-Virumaa until 2030. The current action plan was valid only until this year. Now, however, a new brainstorming is needed in cooperation with the local community.

Today, together with Commissioner for Energy Kadri Simson and Minister of Economic Affairs and Infrastructure Taavi Aasa, I met with representatives of local businesses, local governments and state agencies. We discussed the challenges and future directions of Ida-Virumaa, focusing on the oil shale sector and employment in the county.

Thanks for the good observations and ideas!

Meeting with the community. We hope that the views of the people of Ida-Virumaa will be taken into account when making decisions. We expect to be even more involved.

Today, the council of the Estonian Language Revolution Network will convene for its first meeting. The meeting will take place in Narva at the Estonian Language House. Irene Käosaar, the head of the Integration Foundation, Ilmar Tomusk, the director of the Language Inspectorate, and Riina Koolmeister, the head of the State Language Council, have been invited to the meeting of the Supervisory Board. Kohtla-Järve Gymnasium
20 January 2020 at 18:10 ·

Kohtla-Järve Gymnasium invites high school high schools from all over Estonia to participate in the research competition Future Starts Here - Kohtla-Järve. The format of the competition is aimed at popularizing the field of natural and exact sciences and technology (LTT) for high school students through interdisciplinary team challenges seeking the activity of scientific students.

We all know the science show Rocket 69 - we continue to fly, but in our chosen orbit.

How to generate electricity from handy tools, build a wind generator or solve the task of visual cryptography?

You can find out and take part by joining a 6-member team with the school, registering and participating in the 8-9. April in Kohtla-Järve.

We expect one 6-member team from each state gymnasium to participate, 2 students from each study level (10th-12th grade). The first day takes place with interesting challenges in theory and practice in science and science, and in IT and collaboration skills and the use of knowledge in laboratory settings. The second day is spent in nature, and in addition to smartness, you also need dexterity, speed and courage to decide in special conditions.

We guarantee the accommodation and meals for the participants, the transport costs must be borne by the participants themselves upon arrival. The team of the first year winners is expected to participate in the Future Starts Here - Kohtla-Järve, International Students Challenge 2020 international competition, which will take place on April 29-30, 2020 at Kohtla-Järve Gymnasium.

Future starts here - You can register your school team for the Kohtla-Järve 2020 competition until February 3 here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdm7663JAss-wkyw2u1_1DpEa5St4tYdChO_zk-rHWMfiTDcw/viewform

The progress of the competition can be partly watched on live TV. More detailed instructions for preparation and arrival will be sent to the registrants.

The implementation of the competition is supported by TAL TECH Virumaa College, Eesti Energia AS and Science Center AHHAA.

We live in a difficult time, when each person has to make a personal decision about what is right and what is wrong. TalTech Virumaa College Oil Shale Competence Center
13 November 2019 at 12:55 ·

Hella Riisalu, a senior researcher at the Oil Shale Competence Center of Tallinn University of Technology's Virumaa College, shares her knowledge on the topic - co-pyrolysis and oil production. Riisalu admits that excessive carbon dioxide and methane in the atmosphere are becoming a serious environmental problem and have triggered climate panic and made environmental protection a profitable industry in its own right.
Unsorted, unwashed waste with different components has little to do but incinerate. In practice, however, the alternative is to use pyrolysis, or heating without atmospheric oxygen, to produce gas, oil and semi-coke.
PKK studies show that pyrolysis of 100% plastic waste varies greatly depending on the composition of the waste. The result of the co-pyrolysis process of oil shale and waste is successful up to a ratio of 50:50. The process of co-pyrolysis of residual oil shale products (crushed stone, ash, semi-coke), sand and plastic waste may allow the use of up to 80% plastic waste in the mixture for some components.
Thank you, Hella Riisalu, for inviting me to think out of the frame!

Very exciting presentation!

TalTech Virumaa College Oil Shale Competence Center
13 November 2019 at 12:38 ·

From the XI oil shale conference!
The effect of oil shale ash on tree growth and vegetation in the abandoned peat mining area of ​​Puhatu is introduced by Katri Ots, a senior researcher at the Estonian University of Life Sciences. One way to move towards a low-carbon economy is to afforest abandoned mining areas. The presentation shows that the planted plants are growing well, the undergrowth is not very good. The thorns and leaves of the trees are larger than in unfertilized areas. The use of oil shale ash as a fertilizer binds CO2 emissions due to plants. Oil shale ash could be mixed with wood ash as it has a greater effect.
Thank you, Katri, for a very exciting presentation!

Stay tuned!

TalTech Virumaa College Oil Shale Competence Center
13 November 2019 at 12:24 pm ·

XI Oil Shale Conference "In the Wind of Change". TalTech professor Alar Konist explains that oil shale ash does not differ (negatively) from coal ash. Yes, oil shale ash is dangerous, but not more dangerous than coal ash. Coal ash is not considered a hazardous waste in the EU and America. As oil shale ash must be treated as hazardous waste in Estonia, it makes it significantly more difficult to recover it compared to non-hazardous waste.
Using oil shale in CO2 neutrality - an insurmountable problem or opportunity? Oil shale burning is not only for electricity production but also for oil production. The result depends on the technology. In addition, an environmental impact and life cycle analysis is needed.
Should CO2 be used for chemicals or rather buried? From an ethical point of view, it would probably be more appropriate to use it, but it must be assessed that no greater damage is done to the environment.
Thank you, Professor Konist, for sharing your knowledge.

Yesterday I was full of meetings in Kohtla-Järve and Jõhvi in ​​Ida-Virumaa. I attended the state gymnasium in both cities and met with the school management. Jõhvi State Gymnasium has been running well for four years, because there are far more people who want to study at the school than there are places. The main criterion for admission is proficiency in the Estonian language. However, Kohtla-Järve State Gymnasium, which has been operating for the first weeks, is still trying to break taboos and convince parents that education in Estonian will create a more secure future for their children. The main issue in the coming years will be the level of Estonian language education in basic schools. I think that one of the possibilities could be to consider the nationalization of basic schools on the example of upper secondary schools, even as a pilot project in Ida-Virumaa. At TalTech Virumaa College in Kohtla-Järve, I met with lecturers and got acquainted with the school. The director of the college Mare Roosileht is the real soul of the school and the promoter of education in Estonian in Kohtla-Järve. The College also has an oil shale competence center, which is unique in the world in its ability to analyze oil shale products. Their knowledge must be thoroughly listened to and taken into account when deciding on the future of Estonian oil shale use. I ended the day with the presentation of my book DISTANCE TIME in Jõhvi Library and gave a longer interview to journalist Teet Korsten.

Announcement from our good partner Madis Moor, Tallinn University of Technology:

HTec Baltic's first CNC trainers 'conference will take place at Tallinn University of Technology (Pärnu mnt 62, Tallinn) from October 2-3, 2019. The CNC trainers' conference is for everyone who participates in promoting CNC education - we welcome all trainers from Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Finland. The conference will be held in English

Our goal is to bring together active CNC trainers from the Baltics and Scandinavia to discuss and share best practices and raise the level of CNC teaching in the region.

On the first day, presentations will be given to share new ideas and insights. There will also be a group discussion to share your experiences with trainers in the local region. In the second part of the day, workshops will take place, the topics of which will be the branches related to the CNC field: CAD / CAM software, cutting tools, tooling, measurement techniques on the example of CMM and demos on Haas cutting machines. In addition, there is an opportunity to participate in a programming-turning competition for trainers.

On the second day, a visit to industrial companies will take place in Tallinn. Transport by conference organizers.

To register for the first CNC Trainers Conference in the Baltics, use the link below:

The delegation of Polotsk State University was on a visit to Virumaa College of Tallinn University of Technology (TalTech) from 3 to 7 June, 2019. The purpose of the visit was to get acquainted with the use of ICT in the study process of Virumaa College to apply this knowledge to improve the quality of education in Polotsk State University.
According to Mare Roosileht, the Director for Development of Virumaa College of TalTech Belarusians were introduced first of all to industry 4.0 and to the training of IT specialists. The meetings with partner-enterprises were arranged to share experience on cooperation in the organization of practice and development of study programs. A tour of the methodological, technical laboratories of TalTech and the innovative and business center Mektory was made during the visit.
“At present there is a big shortage of specialists in the industry and in the service sector of Belarus who would know the processes of digitalization. Since TalTech and Virumaa College have a lot of experience in this area, we are ready to share it with the Management and lecturers of Polotsk State University, ”explained Roosileht.
Previously, Virumaa College collaborated with Polotsk State University in the development of Fuel Chemistry and Technology master's degree program.
The delegation from Polotsk State University was represented by 6 lecturers of information technology, power engineering, electronics and fuel chemistry.
The costs associated with the activities of the joint project for the development of the curriculum are covered from the development and humanitarian aid of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Estonia.

Thank you, Maris Lauri, for your direct questions and clear message.

Maris Lauri
9 January 2019 at 19:30 ·

I submitted a written question to the Minister of Education and Research on upper secondary education in Ida-Virumaa. Narva does not want to come to the state gymnasium, the results of the state exams of Jõhvi gymnasium could be better and now a number of questions have arisen about the state gymnasium to be built in Kohtla-Järve. I hope that the questions of a member of the Riigikogu will make the Minister look for a solution to his problems.
But the questions are:
1. What has the Ministry of Education and Research done as a school operator to improve the quality of teaching at Jõhvi Gymnasium? What efforts have been made to strengthen the management of the school and to find teachers with a very good command of Estonian?
2. In what condition is the construction of a state gymnasium in Narva? What have you done as a minister over the past year to get the state gymnasium to Narva?
3. Why was it decided to establish a state gymnasium in Kohtla-Järve, even though there is already another state gymnasium nearby and due to the declining population it may be difficult to find enough students in several state gymnasiums? Was the decision taken into account the fact that it is difficult to find teachers who are fluent in Estonian and whose mother tongue is Estonian, and it would be more expedient to develop one strong upper secondary school with all the necessary teachers who also have a sufficient workload? When making the decision, were the possible negative effects of the closure of Kohtla-Järve Järve Gymnasium as a very strong Estonian-language gymnasium on the Estonian community and the emigration of Estonians from the region due to the decrease in good educational opportunities assessed?
4. What is the idea of ​​the future of Kohtla-Järve State Gymnasium as a representative of the Minister of Education and Research as a school administrator? Please provide precise explanations regarding the fields of study and the language of instruction, as well as how it is planned to find teachers with a high level of professional Estonian or mother tongue in the new upper secondary school in an area where finding such teachers has been a problem for decades?
5. The local community has repeatedly pointed out that the principal of the new state gymnasium does not address the substantive issues necessary for the opening of the gymnasium: has not met with local, potential parents, has not been able to present a clear vision of possible fields of study, etc. What does the Minister intend to do to ensure that the principal of the upper secondary school takes over the management of the upper secondary school?
6. Does and when does the school teacher meet the local Estonian-speaking community and become interested in real developments, rather than apparently accepting the reassuring but inadequate messages presented by the principal, which seek to hide the local people's real concern for children's education and the survival of the Estonian community?
